newsitem.title: UK: UK Conservative leaders back members' votes call.
newsitem.headline: UK Conservative leaders back members' votes call.

text.p: Two of the six contenders for the leadership of Britain's opposition Conservatives bowed on Friday to demands for a bigger say for grassroots members in deciding who should head the party.

But William Hague and Stephen Dorrell said they accepted a decision taken on Thursday by the party's 164 MPs that they alone should vote in the current contest to decide who should take over from John Major.

Hague, the frontrunner according to the bookmakers, said in a speech in Bristol that if he became leader he would call a special party conference at which he would seek endorsement in a secret ballot.
"Without that endorsement I would not continue to serve. A new leader has to have the support of the whole party," Hague said.
Dorrell, a moderate outsider in the leadership contest, said it must be the last at which MPs alone took the decision.
He published in advance comments he will make to a news conference in Scotland on Saturday.
In them, he says: "Future leadership elections must give every member of the party a right to vote on the basis of one-member, one-vote within an electoral college."
There have been howls of protest from party figures at the decision to restrict voting in the June 10 election to MPs.

"It is a huge disappointment. It shows an arrogance on the part of the parliamentary party, of the kind which lost us the last election," said John Strafford, a member of the party's National Executive. -- London Newsroom +44 171 542 7950
